title: 114_s546
content: The "RESPONSE Act of 2016" establishes the Railroad Emergency Services Preparedness, Operational Needs, and Safety Evaluation Subcommittee under the Homeland Security Act of 2002. This subcommittee is part of the National Advisory Council and focuses on railroad emergency services preparedness and safety evaluation. The Railroad Emergency Services Preparedness, Operational Needs, and Safety Evaluation Subcommittee includes key members such as the Deputy Administrator of FEMA, Chief Safety Officer of PHMSA, Director of Office of Emergency Communications, and others from relevant agencies. The Railroad Emergency Services Preparedness, Operational Needs, and Safety Evaluation Subcommittee includes key members appointed by the co-chairpersons, such as representatives from the Federal Railroad Administration, Transportation Security Administration, Coast Guard, Environmental Protection Agency, and other qualified individuals with technical expertise in rail emergency response issues. The Railroad Emergency Services Preparedness, Operational Needs, and Safety Evaluation Subcommittee addresses rail emergency response issues with members from various disciplines. The RESPONSE Subcommittee includes emergency management providers, government officials, and individuals with technical expertise. The RESPONSE Subcommittee includes representatives from the rail industry, rail labor, oil transportation providers, the communications industry, emergency response providers, training providers, tribal organizations, technical experts, and vendors/manufacturers of emergency responder services. The RESPONSE Subcommittee, comprised of various stakeholders, will be co-chaired by members from specific groups. The initial meeting must occur within 90 days of the RESPONSE Act of 2016 enactment. Consultation with relevant agencies, research entities, and academic institutions not represented on the Subcommittee is required. The RESPONSE Subcommittee will develop recommendations for improving emergency responder training and resource allocation for hazardous materials incidents involving railroads, including training for responders in small communities near railroads. This includes analyzing the ease of access to relevant training for State and local emergency responders. The RESPONSE Subcommittee will analyze the number of individuals being trained, applicants, demand, challenges, and projected needs for improving emergency responder training and resource allocation for hazardous materials incidents involving railroads. The RESPONSE Subcommittee will evaluate the modernization of training course content for rail hazardous materials incidents, focusing on oil shipments by rail. This includes assessing course opportunities, adapting to emerging trends, and improving access for emergency responders. They will also identify overlaps in training content and develop complementary courses among different entities. Additionally, they will explore online and mobile training options, as well as assess funding levels for training at various levels of government and non-governmental organizations. The curr_chunk focuses on evaluating funding levels for training emergency responders for rail hazardous materials incidents, including identifying overlap in resource allocations, cost-saving measures, leveraging government and nongovernmental funding, adapting priority settings for funding allocations, and assessing historic funding levels across Federal agencies and the private sector. The curr_chunk discusses integrating commodity flow studies, mapping, and databases for emergency responders, as well as improving access to communication technology. Additionally, it mentions the submission of a report to the National Advisory Council within a year of the enactment of the RESPONSE Act of 2016. The curr_chunk outlines the process for reviewing and approving recommendations from the RESPONSE Subcommittee, including specifying timeframes for implementation and identifying recommendations requiring congressional action. The National Advisory Council reviews the report within 30 days and may request additional information for approval. Once approved, the recommendations are submitted to the co-chairpersons of the Subcommittee. The RESPONSE Subcommittee, along with various congressional committees, oversees updates and oversight activities related to emergency response efforts. Annual updates are provided to the specified committees after the submission of reports by the National Advisory Council. The RESPONSE Subcommittee coordinates the implementation of recommendations and terminates within 90 days after submitting a report to congressional committees. The curr_chunk is about the roles of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States as President of the Senate.
